DOC.HEAD: Soviets Ready to Aid Romania with Medical Help, But no Soldiers
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet officials on Saturday sent medical help and urged Warsaw Pact allies to support the uprising that ousted Nicolae Ceausescu in Romania. They all but ruled out military intervention. ``We have to support them from the point of view of medical help and maybe some other kinds of help, but to bring in forces, I think that's impermissible,'' Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov said. ``We mustn't repeat mistakes,'' he told reporters at the Congress of People's Deputies, the Soviet Parliament. ``Not long ago we gave our evaluation to 1968 in Czechoslovakia. That was on Dec. 4, and should we repeat something like that a few days later?'' Ryzhkov was referring to a Warsaw Pact statement that condemned the 1968 invasion of Czechoslovakia to crush the ``Prague Spring'' reforms. The irony in this instance would be the scenario of Soviet troops helping to oust the vestiges of a Stalinist regime that, of all the nations in the Soviet bloc, most resembles the rigid system prior to the rise of Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Romanian TV, in the hands of the opposition, said the Soviet Embassy had pledged to send personnel and equipment to aid the uprising. The Soviet news agency Tass said Gorbachev told Parliament the Kremlin ``had decided to appeal to the governments of the Warsaw Pact states with the aim of coordinated efforts in providing support to the people of Romania.'' The Soviet Red Cross, Ministry of Health and other organizations were working with similar organizations in France and Eastern Europe to provide medicine and specialists, he said. ``The first planes with medicines and urgent supplies have already arrived in Bucharest,'' Tass quoted Gorbachev as saying. ``But they still are being held up in the Bucharest airport, which is blockaded.'' Gorbachev said ``a number of other measures'' were being worked out with Warsaw Pact allies, and that a special working group was monitoring events in Romania. He provided no other details. Tass issued a government declaration that said ``the Soviet Union is ready to render rapid and effective humanitarian aid to the Romanian people and the new leadership of the country to liquidate the consequences of the tragic events of recent days.'' Another Tass dispatch said some of the wounded were likely to be evacuated to Moldavia, a Soviet republic bordering Romania. Moldavians are ethnically very close to Romanians and speak an almost identical language. Their region belonged to Romania before World War II. Tass said a building housing families of the Soviet trade delegation in Bucharest was in the line of fire between pro- and anti-Ceausescu forces and that fires had started in the building. ``Tass was told by the Soviet Embassy in Romania that the property of many Soviet institutions in Romania has been considerably damaged, and that there are wounded among their staff members,'' it said. It gave no details. ``The lives of Soviet people, including women and children, are in serious danger,'' Tass said. ``The Soviet Union cannot remain indifferent to the fate of Soviet citizens and demands that those who have unleashed the above actions, endangering the lives of Soviet people, should immediately stop them,'' it said. Official Radio Moscow said Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze met with U.S. Ambassador Jack F. Matlock and told him the Soviet Union regarded the events in Romania as an ``expression of will by the Romanian people, seeking to renew society through democracy.'' Soviet media have pounced on the uprising in Romania, providing readers and listeners with startling detail of the battle. Ceausescu resisted the kind of reforms the Soviets encouraged in Eastern Europe. Romania remained part of the Soviet bloc, but relations between Gorbachev and Ceausescu were notably cool. They last met early in December in Moscow, when Tass described their meeting in terms that left little doubt of sharp disagreement.
